turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about J. C. Leyendecker.
turn.1: What were J. C. Leyendecker's early years like?
turn.2: After studying drawing and anatomy under John H. Vanderpoel at the Chicago Art Institute, J. C. and younger brother Frank enrolled in the Académie Julian in Paris for a year, where they were exposed to the work of Toulouse-Lautrec, Jules Chéret, and also Alphonse Mucha, a leader in the French Art Nouveau movement.
turn.3: Where did they return to after Paris?
turn.4: In 1899, the Leyendecker brothers returned to America and set up residence in an apartment in Hyde Park, Illinois.
turn.5: Did they remain in Hyde Park?
turn.6: They had a studio in Chicago's Fine Arts Building at 410 South Michigan Ave.
turn.7: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.8: On May 20 of that year, Joe received his first commission for a "Saturday Evening Post" cover – the beginning of his forty-four-year association with the most popular magazine in the country.
turn.9: Did he do any other work with Saturday Evening Post?
turn.10: Ultimately he would produce 322 covers for the magazine, introducing many iconic visual images and traditions including the New Year's Baby, the pudgy red-garbed rendition of Santa Claus, flowers for Mother's Day, and firecrackers on the 4th of July.
turn.11: Where did he go after Chicago?
turn.12: In 1900, Joe, Frank, and their sister Mary moved to New York City, then the center of the US commercial art, advertising and publishing industries.
